page.title: 05CLIMATE IN POLWARTH
page.content: RAINFALL ON THIS EASTERN SIDE OF THE SCOTTISH BORDERS & AT THIS HEIGHT OF 200M ABOVE SEA LEVEL, IS NOT VERY HIGH, GENERALLY ABOUT 24.5". THE SUMMER OF 1985 WAS UNUSUALLY WET BUT WAS BALANCED BY A VERY DRY OCT., SO THAT A DIFFICULT, BUT NOT HOPELESS, HARVEST HAS LED TO A GOOD DRILLING SEASON & MANY FIELDS ARE AGAIN GREEN WELL BEFORE WINTER. RECENTLY THE AUTUMN ASPECT OF THE AREA HAS ALTERED AS FARMERS SOW AT THE BACKEND & NO LONGER RISK WAITING FOR THE SPRING, WHICH IS OFTEN LATE, COLD, WET & SHORT. THIS MEANS A VERY BUSY HARVEST TIME WITH A LARGER WORKFORCE & MORE MACHINERY & VERY FEW STUBBLE FIELDS, WITH THE EFFECT THAT HAS ON THE PARTRIDGE POPULATION & THE HUNTING COMMUNITY, IN THIS AREA THE BERWICKSHIRE HUNT.
